title: Welcome to IP&T 692R-R Class;
description: Welcome to our new blog; We hope you enjoy this semester learning R!

title: Class 1- Introduction to R and R-Studio

#write select without creating an object
?dplyr::select
select(starwars,gender, mass, height, species)


# A tibble: 87 × 4
   gender     mass height species
   <chr>     <dbl>  <int> <chr>  
 1 masculine    77    172 Human  
 2 masculine    75    167 Droid  
 3 masculine    32     96 Droid  
 4 masculine   136    202 Human  
 5 feminine     49    150 Human  
 6 masculine   120    178 Human  
 7 feminine     75    165 Human  
 8 masculine    32     97 Droid  
 9 masculine    84    183 Human  
10 masculine    77    182 Human  
# … with 77 more rows

Data1<-select(starwars,gender, mass, height, species)
Data1.1<- filter(Data1, species == "Human")



Using piping operator


FinalData<-starwars %>% 
  select(gender, mass, height, species) %>% 
  filter(species=="Human") 



Lets omit NA and see the results


FinalData1<-starwars %>% 
  select(gender, mass, height, species) %>% 
  filter(species=="Human") %>% 
  na.omit()

FinalData1


# A tibble: 22 × 4
   gender     mass height species
   <chr>     <dbl>  <int> <chr>  
 1 masculine    77    172 Human  
 2 masculine   136    202 Human  
 3 feminine     49    150 Human  
 4 masculine   120    178 Human  
 5 feminine     75    165 Human  
 6 masculine    84    183 Human  
 7 masculine    77    182 Human  
 8 masculine    84    188 Human  
 9 masculine    80    180 Human  
10 masculine    77    170 Human  
# … with 12 more rows

Now let’s create a new variable called heightM (heigh in meters)


FinalData2<-starwars %>% 
  select(gender, mass, height, species) %>%
  filter(species=="Human") %>% 
  na.omit() %>% 
  mutate(heightM = height/100 ) %>% 
  mutate(BMI=mass/height) 
FinalData2


# A tibble: 22 × 6
   gender     mass height species heightM   BMI
   <chr>     <dbl>  <int> <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>
 1 masculine    77    172 Human      1.72 0.448
 2 masculine   136    202 Human      2.02 0.673
 3 feminine     49    150 Human      1.5  0.327
 4 masculine   120    178 Human      1.78 0.674
 5 feminine     75    165 Human      1.65 0.455
 6 masculine    84    183 Human      1.83 0.459
 7 masculine    77    182 Human      1.82 0.423
 8 masculine    84    188 Human      1.88 0.447
 9 masculine    80    180 Human      1.8  0.444
10 masculine    77    170 Human      1.7  0.453
# … with 12 more rows

  # MUTATE- we could create a new variable or change the variable. I suggest creating a new variable.





FinalData3<-starwars %>% 
  select(gender, mass, height, species) %>%
  filter(species=="Human") %>% 
  na.omit() %>% 
  mutate(heightM = height/100 ) %>% 
  mutate(BMI=mass/height) %>% 
  group_by(gender) %>% 
  summarize(mean_height=mean(height))
FinalData3


# A tibble: 2 × 2
  gender    mean_height
  <chr>           <dbl>
1 feminine         160 
2 masculine        183.



FinalData4<-starwars %>% 
  select(gender, mass, height, species) %>%
  filter(species=="Human") %>% 
  na.omit() %>% 
  mutate(heightM = height/100 ) %>% 
  mutate(BMI=mass/height) %>% 
  group_by(gender) %>% 
  summarize(mean_BMI=mean(BMI)) 
FinalData4


# A tibble: 2 × 2
  gender    mean_BMI
  <chr>        <dbl>
1 feminine     0.351
2 masculine    0.475

# Changing the type of the variable in r

hist(starwars$height)



starwars$hair_color<-as.factor(starwars$hair_color)

plot(starwars$hair_color)




Time for practicing
Time for selecting different variables.
using everything else


sw<-starwars %>% 
  select(name, mass, height, sex, everything()) %>% 
  rename(name1=name) %>% 
  rename(weight=mass)
#rename: we start with the new name and then add the old one.



recoding


sw$sex<-as.factor(sw$sex)

#Removing object
rm ()

#
swRec<-sw %>% 
  select(name1, weight, height, sex, gender) %>% 
  rename(name=name1) %>% 
  mutate(heightM= height/100) %>% 
  filter(gender %in% c("masculine", "feminine")) %>% 
  mutate(gender=recode(gender, masculine = "M", feminine = "F")) %>% 
  mutate(size=height>1 &weight>75) %>%  # we got true and false
  mutate(size= if_else(size==TRUE, "Big", "Small"))
# %in% explain that it mean include everything. IN filter, it could be used filter(gender=="masculine"| gender== "feminine"). In this case we use concatenate meaning everything inside should be filtered





data("msleep")
a<-msleep %>% 
  select(name, sleep_total) %>% 
  filter(sleep_total>18)
  
b<-msleep %>% 
  select(name, sleep_total) %>% 
  filter(!sleep_total>18) # ! all variables NOT bigger than 18

c<-msleep %>% 
  select(name, order, bodywt, sleep_total) %>% 
  filter(order=="Primates", bodywt>20)

d<-msleep %>% 
  select(name, order, bodywt, sleep_total) %>% 
  filter(order=="Primates"| bodywt>20) # | means or (both criteria needs to be satisfied)

e<- msleep %>% 
  select(name, order, bodywt, sleep_total) %>% 
  filter(between(sleep_total, 10, 18))

f<- msleep %>% 
  select(name, order, bodywt, sleep_total) %>% 
  filter(near(sleep_total, 10, tol = 0.5))

g<- msleep %>% 
  select(name, order, bodywt, sleep_total, conservation) %>% 
  filter(is.na(conservation)) 

h<- msleep %>% 
  select(name, order, bodywt, sleep_total, conservation) %>% 
  filter(order=="Rodentia" & !is.na(conservation)) #needs to satisfy both conditions

#Select and mutation
Give multiple ways to select dep_time, dep_delay, arr_time, and arr_delay from the flights data frame.


variables <- c("dep_time", "dep_delay", "arr_time", "arr_delay")
departure_delays <- select(flights, variables)
departures_delays <-
  select(flights, dep_time, dep_delay, arr_time, arr_delay)
departures_delays <-
  select(flights, starts_with("dep"), starts_with("arr"))
departures_delays <-
  select(flights, ends_with("time"), ends_with("delay"))
departures_delays <- select(flights, 4, 6:7, 9)



Calculate the difference between dep_time and sched_dep_time and compare the result with dep_delay. How do we explain the difference?


departure_comparison <-
  transmute(flights,
            dep_time,
            sched_dep_time,
            dep_delay,
            time_difference = dep_time - sched_dep_time,
            same = (dep_delay == time_difference))

#Exploratory Data Analysis Formulate questions about your data Investigate answers to questions by visualizing, transforming, and modelling Evolve and spawn new questions based on what is learned Data cleaning also involves visualization, transformation, and modelling.
#Questions “The key to asking quality questions is to generate a large quantity of questions.”
##Two types of questions:
How is a variable distributed? How are variables related to each other? Basic definitions Variable: quantity, quality, or property Value: state or level of a variable when it is measured Observation: “a set of measurements under similar conditions” Tabular data: “a set of values, each associated with a variable and an observation.” ##Distribution Possible values Frequency or probability of observing values Describing the distribution gives us a basic set of questions to start asking. These in turn provoke additional questions. When considering a distribution, we should organize our preliminary investigation around:
##Location or central tendency (mean and median) Scale or spread (sd, range, and interquartile range) Symmetry Outliers
